subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] RE: regional accents
msgSnippet: I see your point but English is going to fragment anyway just as Latin did as Rome s empire faded. These processes are slow but inevitable. At the moment the
messageBody:
I see your point but English is going to fragment anyway just as Latin did as Rome's empire faded. These processes are slow but inevitable.

At the moment the language is sustained and kept standard by the American cultural and business empire. To demonstrate that, I even see singers from Australia mimicking a standard type of American accent in their singing. It seems a obvious to them that they should sing in an American accent.

I disagree about Literacy. Have another look at English itself, Shakespeare or Chaucer for example. Literacy like all art never fades, it's what human's do. We can't help but do it.

Then we have the computer generation with their texting shorthand. I bet you, texting shorthand will evolve the next standardized spelling over the next 100 years.

The amusing thing is that non-English speakers are as good as the native speakers when it comes to texting. Already literature is being written in it and the Internet is driving it.

I don't think that Quickscipt is doomed or won't somehow take off in some quarters. What happens in the future is anyone's guess.

Quickscript's real strength is that it's designed for English. Just as the Arabic alphabet was designed for Arabic and is terrible for Urdu and Persian. Or Cyrillic was designed for Russian and is terrible for Mongol or Kazak.




On Tuesday, 12 November 2013 4:13 PM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
 
weshdim@... scripsit:

> I decided to learn the alphabet for note taking and diary entries,
> some "cryptic" text on some art work as well as the joy of casual
> calligraphy in a beautiful alphabet.

Sure, for personal uses, spell any way you like. But no language has
ever sustained literacy without spelling standards, and I don't think
anyone wants to see written English even more fragmented than it is:
"Kiwi dole bludge rort probe", anyone?

> Quickscript clearly reveals a language in a constant state of change
> and the strength of quickscript is that it is an excellent vehicle
> to support the evolution.

Chainge is one thing. Muchul isolation is another.

--
The first thing you learn in a lawin' family John Cowan
is that there ain't no definite answers cowan@...
to anything. --Calpurnia in To Kill A Mockingbird
